titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. VI: Wednesday. The Morning was employed in closing the Journal of the departed year; and with the Sentiments befitting the Commencement of the new one— Of the last year, my Journal has absorbed an undue proportion, and led to arrears of Correspondence which are yet to be retrieved.— A sense of public duty induced me to begin the year with some official act; I made a draft of a Note to Lord Castlereagh, on the case of the Ship Hope, concerning which I had spoken to him at our last Interview; and enclosed it to J. A. Smith requesting him to copy and send it immediately— I answered also the Note yesterday received from Lord Holland. Received a Note from Lord Castlereagh, dated yesterday, and informing me that the Lords of the Treasury had directed the Commissioners of the Customs to grant the permission requested for the Samoset. The Evening’s Post brought an enclosed Packet for C. Hughes, and a Letter to my wife from her brother. Walk to Brentford and through Sion House Park— Evening in my Cabinet— Miss Bond paid my wife a visit. Says she intends going to America, next Spring.

2. V: After commencing the diary of the year, I determined to turn my immediate attention to the arrears of my correspondence, and wrote an answer to H. Visger, Consul at Bristol— Began also a Letter to my father. But from Breakfast time I met with some interruption— Received a Letter from Miss Mary Clitherow, informing me that she does not expect to have occasion to remove soon to this house; that she will be glad to have us remain in it as tenants, and will give us ample notice if she should have hereafter a necessity for our removal.— I answered her Letter by a Note enclosing the amount of the Rent due till next Monday, and assuring her that I will give her as early notice as possible, if I should be under the necessity of removing myself. She replied by a short note in the Evening. Walked with George to Brentford and through Sion House Park. On returning home, I took up the Papers of the case of the Mary, with the intention of addressing a Note concerning it to Lord Castlereagh— The perusal of the Papers however occupied me till dinner time, and I found there were documents for which I must write to Mr Glennie, before preparing my Note— Evening Cards with my wife and John— By the Morning’s Post I received Letters from A. H. Everett, and President J. T. Kirkland of Harvard University; both introducing a Mr Isaac Boyle, who left them at the Office— Boyle comes to bespeak instruments for the Observatory.— The President mentions that they had received Bode’s Charts, last July from Hamburg; and mentions that S. Bourne’s son was there, preparing to enter the Sophomore Class.

3. VI: Began the morning by writing short Letters to J. S. Glennie, and R. Mowbray. Received by the first Post a Letter from T. Aspinwall; unsigned—by the second one from C. Hughes: and by the third one from Mr Eustis at Bruxelles. Hughes has just returned from Brighton with a bad Cold. I finished a long Letter to my father, and on returning from a walk to Hanwell and Ealing, answered Hughes. Passed the Evening at Cards with the Children. Ellen and Sophia Nicholas were here this Morning— The Message of the President of the United States to Congress at the opening of the Session was published in the Courier of New-Years day, with an editorial note of approbation, repeated with some mixture of foolish insolence in the Paper of last Evening.

4. IV:45. Wrote short Letters to Coll. Aspinwall, and to W. Vaughan; and made out my quarterly Account. Went into London with George, who left me at Hyde Park corner. I called upon General von Neuffer the Wurtemberg Minister, with three Notes which I have received from him containing enquiries concerning Wurtembergers deceased at New-York, and Philadelphia— The first was of 16 July last, concerning Anton Henry Bach, who died at New-York in 1798. I had requested J. A. Smith to write to some friend at New-York to make the enquiries. He wrote to James Smith, and a few days since received his answer which I took with me to General Neuffer. He desired me to leave it with him as he was desirous of sending it to his Government, and said he would retain a copy of it here— The second was of 4. December, a certificate of the Minister of the German Lutheran Church at Philadelphia, authenticated by the Mayor of Philadelphia, but of which further authentication was requested. I asked the General if mine would answer— I knew that R. Wharton was Mayor of Philadelphia, and had no doubt it was his signature, and the Seal of the City that were upon the paper. He said my certificate to that effect to which he would then add his own, would suffice.— I retained the paper to make out my Certificate upon it. The third was of the 23d. of December, asking me to obtain a certificate of the decease of a man named Schwarz at New-York and information concerning the Estate left by him— I observed that this could be obtained only in the same manner as I had got that relative to Bach, and enquired whether that would be satisfactory. He said it would, and that he would pay every expence that
might be occasioned by it. He apologized to me for giving me so much trouble about these concerns of individuals. He said that the Governments in Germany were so organized that all such business was transacted through the medium of ministerial departments. A note to the Minister of foreign Affairs, produced a reference to the Minister of the Interior, and there all information upon such Subjects was to be obtained; but it was not so in this Country, nor, he supposed in America; and here when he had enquiries of this kind to make he was obliged to make them not in his Official character; but in his private capacity. He had written so to his Government; but they continued to send him instructions of that sort, and he was obliged to execute them. He thanked me for the attention I had paid to the cases concerning which he had written to me, and offered any services that might be in his power in return— I asked him if there was any Agent or Minister of the Grand Duke of Baden now here. He said none. I said I had a Letter from the President of the United States to the Grand-Duke, which had been sent to me, on the supposition that he had a Minister here, and with Instructions to deliver it to him. I asked him if he could put me in the way of having it transmitted. He said Baden was their next door Neighbour— Not 15 Miles, German, from Stutgard. If I would send him the Letter, he would forward it to his Government, and thence it would be safely transmitted to the Grand Duke. The General then, after noticing the newspaper paragraphs about my being recalled, launched out into general politics, and said he thought the Government here were very much embarrassed; and that they would have a stormy Session of Parliament— I was not of that opinion. Warm debates their probably will be; but a heavy majority of Parliament are pledged body and soul to the Ministers, upon every object they may choose to carry; and all Parliament are so pledged, upon every public subject now at issue, that it is not at all from Parliament that the Ministers have any serious difficulty to expect— He then spoke of Spain, and said he strongly suspected Cevallos would be taken again by the king, for the seventh time, to be his prime Minister. That he personally knew Pizarro, who upon this last dismission of Cevallos had taken his place. He was certainly a man of Talents; but a very violent Man. As to the Spanish affairs in South-America, he could make nothing of them; but he believed Spain would never recover her authority over the Colonies— As for us in Germany said he “je crois que nous nous tirerons d’Affaire—” On the sixteenth of this Month we shall have in Wurtemberg a new Constitution, “et une très belle Constitution,” proclaimed. And when we have once begun, Baden must follow the example— Bavaria perhaps will be reluctant, but must at last prendre son parti, and that will give an irresistible impulse to the South of Germany—and when that is accomplished the North of Germany cannot linger long to come into the change. So according to the General, every thing is to be done by the example of Wurtemberg— I observed that there appeared to be much difficulty to the introduction of a Constitution in Prussia— He said there was; but Prussia would get along. The great misfortune was that the Emperor of Austria, who was one of the best and worthiest and most honourable men in the world, could not however endure to hear the very word Constitution mentioned. He had a horror even of the word— I said I supposed that was the result of the French Revolution— And besides, that no absolute Prince, such as all the Sovereigns of Germany were, could be expected to relish a word, the only meaning of which must operate as a limitation of their own authority— He said that his Country, Wurtemberg was an exception to my remark that all the German Governments were absolute (I had myself excepted the imperial free cities.) But Wurtemberg had had a Constitution, under which the People had lived, free and contented more than two Centuries— I spoke of the contests which I had heard mentioned as prevailing between the late king, and the States, both at the beginning and the close of his reign. He said he might now say it without hesitation, and it was too notorious to be denied; that the late king was a violent despot. But that he had never been able to overcome the resistance of the States, until he made his league with Napoleon, who said to him in no other than these words “chassez ces bougres.”—and who supported him in it.— But I observed, that in the last days of the late king, and even since the accession of his Son, I had heard the States were insisting on the antient Constitution of the Country. It was impossible he said that that should be allowed. The great point for which they contended was not only that all public monies should be levied by them, which was perfectly
proper, but that they should also have the management of its expenditure by a secret Committee of their own which was incompatible with any rational theory, and had been found excessively pernicious by experience. I asked him if there had not been some controversy on the part of certain mediatised Princes. He said yes— They would be very glad to resume the exercise of their Sovereign Authorities; but it was obviously impossible to indulge them in that humour.— I asked him if he thought the new Constitution would give general satisfaction. He had no doubt it would: And the States would have the power of levying all imposts and taxes; and all the accounts of the expenditures of public money would be laid before them— I enquired of the General after my former diplomatic acquaintance— Schenk who is one of the mediatised Counts, is in no public employment— Neuffer spoke of him with great contempt— Frohberg on the contrary he said was a very good man— He has some Commandery of the Teutonic Order; but had declined a diplomatic Mission. Count Beroldingen is now the Minister at St. Petersburg— On leaving the General I called at the French Ambassador’s and left a Card for Count George de Caraman, the Secretary of the Embassy, who brought me a Letter from Mr Gallatin— He was gone to Brighton— Thence I stopped at Richardson’s in Pall Mall, and then proceeded to Craven Street— There found Letters from my father and brother, from T. Auldjo and W. Couling. My father is anxious and urgent in his advice to me to return to America. My brother’s Letter relates to my affairs in his hands. Auldjo writes about his consular Bonds, and expenditures, and Couling about his losses and misfortunes, including his wife the greatest of them all— I went with J. A. Smith to N. 4. Sackville Street Piccadilly, to see Jouffroy the Prussian Chargé d’Affaires, but he was not at home. I stopp’d at Williams the Stationers, on returning to Craven Street. There came visitors to the Office. Mr Thompson the publisher of the Translation of Alcedo’s Dictionary concerning America, for which I subscribed last Summer— He said his Subscription had gone on very rapidly since then; and that he was desirous of collecting materials for a second Edition— Afterwards he said he wished to collect documents of all the changes that had occurred in America since the Period to which his work referred, and to publish it in the form of a Supplement— I advised him to form a correspondence with some of the British Consuls or persons connected with the British Legation in America, and get them to send him the public documents as they are from time to time published, and I recommended to him to take the National Intelligencer— He asked me if I was acquainted with Bouchette’s Maps of Canada— I had seen them, and spoke of them with approbation— I also promised to lend him Pitkin’s Statistical View of the commerce of the United States— He was followed by a Mr Munro, a Mathematical instrument maker, who said he was born at Boston though he had been brought to England in his infancy, and had never since been in America. He came to enquire if I wanted any thing done, in his business, and shewed me a Letter which he had received from Mr Monroe when he was Minister here in 1804. dated 61. Wimpole-Street, and in answer to one which Munro had written to him, apparently making enquiries with a view to trace a kindred between them from the similarity of their names. Mr Monroe says his family went to Virginia about a century ago, and have since constantly remained there. Munro had brought a small brass Bucket which he said was of his own invention, for weighing grain; but I have seen the same before. I took his address and told him if I should have occasion for any thing in his way I would send for him— Hughes came in next, and sat with us till near six O’Clock. He has been to Brighton, and returned in great admiration at the great attentions, paid by the Prince Regent, and all the Nobility there to Mr and Mrs Patterson and the Miss Caton’s. Hughes says that he saw Sir John and Lady Warren there; and that Admiral Cockburn had been to see the Patterson’s— That he told them the Government here had blamed him for having left a house standing at Washington— That his instructions were at the attack upon Baltimore, to burn the town; and that the only thing that could have saved it would have been a contribution large enough to have justified him in breaking his instructions. Hughes talked over a multitude of other subjects; and among the rest gave an account of his reconciliation with Mr Mansfield who married his wife’s Sister— Hughes made a runaway match with Laura Smith, daughter of General Samuel Smith of Baltimore. Mansfield, who is a natural son of Sir James Mansfield late Chief Justice of the Court of Common-Pleas here, went to America, as a supernumerary Secretary to Mr Rose’s Mission; he did not return with Rose, but remained there some time longer, and married General Smith’s eldest daughter Mary. Smith the father was reconciled to Hughes, when he was appointed the Secretary to the Ghent Mission. At that time Hughes came here; but Mansfield and his wife refused to see him— But being now here with his wife, they have made it up; Mansfield made him a formal apology for what had past, which Hughes, accepted, and they are now upon a friendly footing— Hughes had written me, that they
intended to leave London next Friday the tenth, and in the Note that I sent him this Morning I had invited him to come out and dine with us on Thursday. He had not received my Note; but said they had now agreed to leave London on Thursday. And the Patterson’s were to leave Brighton the same day. They were to meet at Dover, and proceed to France together. I then asked him to come and dine with us on Wednesday which he promised he would; though he said perhaps Mrs. Mansfield would insist upon having her Sister with her, the last day of her being in town— Smith had made out several Cards of invitation for Thursday which he now altered to Wednesday— There was a Mr Atkins came in, with a proposal from a man who had invented a new kind of a ship, with three bottoms (which Hughes said should be called La Santissima Trinidad.) and was inclined to dispose of the Invention to the Government of the United States, if I would purchase it for them— He had drawings on paper, shewing the construction of the various part of this vessel, and offered to shew me the model of it. But having no authority to make the purchase on account of the United States, I declined going to see the Model— Smith wrote a Note for me to Mr Hamilton the Under Secretary in the Department of foreign Affairs; and I wrote a Note to General Neuffer, to enclose the President’s Letter to the Grand Duke of Baden— We got home at half past seven— I found a Letter from John Bainbridge asking to see me; and a card of invitation from W. Vaughan.

5. VI— Attended church with my wife and John. George and Charles went to the Dissenters chapel on the Boston Terrace. We had Mr Carr to read prayers for the second Sunday after Christmas; and Mr Milman preached from Psalm II.11—the latter part of the verse—“rejoice with trembling:” The weather prevented me from going out after my return from Church— There was rain, succeeded by a fall of Snow. R. Chichester dined and spent the Evening here. I was occupied all day, excepting when reading the papers, upon the journal of yesterday which however I could not finish.

6. V: Finished the Journal of the 4th: and that of yesterday. My wife went into London, and lodged at Craven-Street. I was employed great part of the day in assorting the Letters which I received in the course of the last year, but left the work imperfect. Wrote despatch 66. to the Secretary of State, and answered T. Auldjo’s Letter yesterday received. Walk to Brentford and Ealing. The Evening’s Post brought a Letter from Hughes, with excuses for his wife’s not coming to dine with us next Wednesday; he says he himself will come; and a Letter from John Chambers a lawyer at Dublin, concerning affairs of Thomas Hunter, a Citizen of South Carolina; and enclosing a Letter from David R. Williams, Governor of South Carolina to me, recommending Hunter to me— Evening passed in anxious solitary reflection.

7. VI:15. Rose at three; but finding it so early, returned to bed, and lay awake till past six. Then wrote until Breakfast time. Last Saturday J. A. Smith had written a Note for me to Hamilton of the foreign Department, asking for an order from the Treasury to the Custom-House for the delivery to me, free of duty, of one Pipe of Madeira, and one Hogshead of Teneriffe wine which I have purchased, and which are lying in the Docks— This Morning I received a Note from Planta, Lord Castlereagh’s private Secretary, answering in the absence of Hamilton, that he has made private enquiry at the Treasury, and finds, that although foreign Ministers may import, Articles for their own use, duty free, that the exemption is not allowed upon Articles which they purchase in this Country. He is apprehensive that this rule, will render ineffectual the application to the Treasury requested by me, and therefore communicates the Circumstance to me— I went to London with John and Charles. Mr John Bainbridge whom I had promised to see at Craven Street came at three O’Clock. He said that an export duty of one per Cent had continued to be levied upon all Articles exported to the United States, notwithstanding the Commercial Convention of 3. July 1815, which was one half per Cent more than the duty levied upon Articles exported to foreign Ports in Europe. As this had appeared to him contrary to the stipulation in the Convention, he had applied to the Board of Trade about it, and they had agreed to return the extra 1/2 per Cent, but a difficulty had arisen as to the time from which the return should commence. They were willing immediately to return, from the time of the ratification of the Convention in America. That was the period from which by the Law of Congress, the extra duties upon British vessels and merchandize had ceased to be levied in the United States. But here there had been some extra-duties, which had ceased immediately after the Convention was concluded; others had ceased from the 17th. of August 1815. The date of the Orders in Council: and now Mr Robinson proposes to return these from theof December 1815 the time of the Ratification in America.
The object, Bainbridge said was of considerable importance to the merchants of the United States; probably upon the whole exportations since the Convention was concluded, not less than £500,000. Sterling. I told him that I had given my opinion both to the Government here, and to that of the United States that the cessation of all the extra-duties on both sides ought to be, from the date of the Convention. It was so expressly stipulated, in the Convention itself by a clause substituted at the instance of the British Government, instead of one proposed by the American Plenipotentiaries that the Convention should take effect from the exchange of the ratifications. The order in Council of 17. August 1815 had been issued upon a representation from me, founded upon this principle, although it had not been fully acted upon, for the order was not made retrospective back to the date of the Treaty. The Law of Congress of the last Session, had fixed upon the date of the ratification. But since then Mr Bagot had addressed to the American Government a demand that the extra duties levied on British vessels and goods in the United States in the interval between the order in Council here, and the exchange of the Ratifications at Washington should be returned— The Secretary of State had answered that this would require the exercise of powers for which the Executive was not competent; but that the subject would be recommended to the attention of Congress at their Session which has now commenced. I had no doubt they would soon act upon it, and hoped they would adopt the date of the convention, as the period from which to commence the return of extra duties— If they did so, I trusted this Government would do the same; and if necessary would make an official application to that effect. I asked Bainbridge to send me a written minute of the nature of this duty which he promised me he would do. Mr A. H. Everett also called at the Office, to advise with me, about the transmission to St. Petersburg of the despatches committed by the Government to his charge— I told him that having advised him after perusal of the Papers to proceed, I had concluded he would go, and had mentioned in a despatch to the Secretary of State the advice that I had given him. He was still very averse to going, on account of his wife, who cannot go with him, and of whom he knows not how to dispose during his absence— But he said he would reflect upon it and make up his mind to-morrow— He told me that he had returned last Summer to Boston with permission from Mr Eustis the Minister to whose Legation he is the Secretary— That on his arrival at Boston he had given notice of it to the Government, who without disapproving it, informed him that his Salary would be stopped from the time of his having left the Hague. When he was charged with the despatches, he was allowed 1000 dollars for his expences and compensation for carrying them, and informed that his Salary would recommence from the 15th. of November. He sailed from Boston the 27th: of that Month— His wife, to marry whom he had gone home is in a situation not well suited to the Journey to St. Petersburg— I was a couple of hours alone at the Office, and amused them with reading some of Dr Franklin’s Letters— Returned home with my wife and children about seven. Mrs Adams who is quite unwell had a fainting fit after dinner.

8. VIII: My wife was unwell great part of the Night, but much better this Morning. I answered Planta’s Note; which occupied the Morning. Walked with George to Brentford and round Sion House Park— Mr and Mrs A. H. Everett, Mr and Mrs. Charles Everett, General Boyd, Messrs Boyle, Hughes, Platt, J. A. Smith and Storer dined with us— Mrs Hughes, G. Joy, and J. C. Montgomery were invited, but sent excuses— Hughes brought out a note from Major Mercer, taking leave, of us and offering his services to take any thing for us to America— He and Mr Leavenworth were out here yesterday, while we were in London— Mr and Mrs and Miss Carr had also been here and left Cards yesterday.— Our company this day were all complaining that the fog had been this Morning so thick in London that it had been scarcely possible at ten O’Clock to see without a candle. We had nothing of such darkness here. In general the wintery atmosphere of London is gloomy beyond that of any other place that I have ever inhabited; while within two or three Miles of the City it is incomparably more cheerful— The four Misses Nicholas were here in the Evening— There was a little Music and singing. Our company left us at about eleven.

9. VII: Fahrenheit 30. Letter from S. Williams, enclosing my account with him balanced to the close of the year. Answered his Letter and wrote a Note to W. Vaughan. My wife went into London with my three Sons. She left them in town for two or three days, and returned home herself to dinner. I walked to Hanwell and Ealing. She brought me out Letters; from J. M. del Real, congratulating me upon my Appointment (as he supposes) of Secretary of State, in the United States; and expressing his wishes for the continuance of the good-Understanding between his Country and mine from General Neuffer, a note in reply to two of mine— From H. G. Spafford of Albany 18. November. He refers to his conversations with Mr Madison and Mr Monroe, nearly two years ago, and hints that he would like to be appointed superintendant of the Patent-Office. He also sends one of his books on the State of New-York, with a Letter to the President of the Linnean Society— My wife received a Letter from Miss Elizabeth Caton at Brighton, requesting permission to send from France, under cover of my privilege, and addressed to me a trunk of Lady’s finery for herself and her Sisters. The weather
was cold and I had a faint and sickly turn for a few minutes after dinner, from which I however shortly recovered.

10. IV:30. Fahrenheit 28. Wrote a Note to Major Mercer; a Letter to John Chambers at Dublin; and a Letter to my brother, which employed me till four in the afternoon with the exception of an hour for breakfast. I received a note from W. Vaughan and a Letter from a man named Brownsmith, who wishes to go to America with his family, and offers himself for my service. I walked to Gunnersbury and Brentford.

11. VI:45. Wrote a Letter to my Mother and went into London alone. I found at Craven Street a Letter from C. Hughes, dated last Evening at Dover. He says he has found my portrait at the Custom-House there which was taken from Connell, and has given directions for having it sent to me. A Mr Joshua Bates of Weymouth, Massachusetts came and took a Passport to go to France. A. H. Everett and Dr Bollmann called at the Office. Everett has finally concluded not to go to St. Petersburg, and I advised him to take the despatches with him, and forward them from Bruxelles by the Post, writing at the same time, himself to Mr Pinkney, explaining the reasons of his omitting the journey in person. I left the boys in town and returned alone home to dinner— Fahrenheit was this Morning at 24. The day cold, and the roads hard frozen. I walked on going into town, nearly as far as Kew-Bridge. Received a reply from S. Williams, who informs me that his Correspondent at New-York, writes him 3. December that Dr. Cook’s Bill on Thomas Storey, (which I gave Williams 27. July for collection) was not accepted, but that assurances were given it should be paid in a few days— Received also under cover from W. Frend a pamphlet just published by him “The National debt in its true colours, with plans for its extinction by honest means.” After dinner this Evening I read Cobbett’s Register.

12. VII. Fahrenheit at 30, and rose in the course of the day to a thaw. I attended Church alone. Prayers for the first Sunday after the Epiphany were read by Mr Carr, and the Sermon was preached by Mr Milman from Malachi I.11. “For, from the rising of the sun even unto the going down of the same, my name shall be great among the Gentiles; and in every place, incense shall be offered unto my name, and a pure offering: for my name shall be great among the heathen, saith the Lord of hosts.” An Epiphany discourse— Mr Milman began with the first Advent Season after his Ordination as a priest to preach a series of Sermons, occasional to the annual festival Seasons recognized by the Church of England. A good practice for a newly ordained preacher of this Church. I wrote a Note to Lord Castlereagh, on the case of the William and Mary. Walk to Brentford. Our Sons returned home from London. R. Chichester dined and spent the Evening with us.

13. V:30. Began the Morning by writing to W. Eustis— Finished it by despatch 67 to the Secretary of State. My wife, with George and John went into London; and took R. Chichester with them. I sent Antoine likewise to town, to attend an auction of furniture. I walked to Gunnersbury and Brentford— I read W. Frend’s pamphlet upon the British National debt. His plans for its extinction are not likely to be successful. One of them is a land-tax of four shillings on the pound connected with a tax of ten per cent on the interest upon the Stocks themselves— A new property tax, more severe than that which has so lately been found insupportable. Another is to open books for voluntary donations to the publick, by the fund holders themselves. A sinking fund of patriotic Sacrifices— But the Stockholders will be apt to enquire why they should give away their property to the Nation more than others. A third scheme is that the part of the sinking fund which has not been pledged to the public Creditors should be applied to the current expenditures of the year; and this part of his projects may probably be carried into effect— He inculcates a very laudable reverence for public faith, and has an exalted idea of the resources of the Nation— He speaks in terms of high commendation of Mr Fox, and with strong censure upon Mr Pitt, though without naming him.

14. VI:45. Sent Antoine to London, to attend an Auction of furniture. Wrote a Note to Lord Castlereagh on the subject of the Eastport revenue Bonds. Letter to my father. Sent the Packets of despatches to J. A. Smith. Walk with George through Sion house park and the village of Isleworth. In the Evening I read three Acts of Cumberland’s Jew. There was this day a conjunction of the Moon, Mars and Jupiter. I saw the Moon and Jupiter, but not Mars, who rises after daybreak. It was nearly full day-light when I rose this Morning.

15. IV:30. I rose in time to have seen the Moon still in conjunction with the two Planets; but the Sky was overcast, and there was a fall of Snow sufficient to cover entirely the ground. I wrote Letters to G. Ludlow at New-York, to S. Bourne at Amsterdam, to J. M. del Real; and began one to W. Plumer, the present Governor of New-Hampshire. I went to London alone called at Aylmer Bourke Lambert’s 26. Grosvenor Street— He was not at home. I left at his house my Card, with H. G. Spafford’s Gazetteer of New-York, and his Letter to the President of the Linnean Society. Mr Lambert is one of the Vice-Presidents. At Craven Street I found General Boyd.— Two Letters for C. Hughes, and one to my wife from her Sister Buchanan, under covers to me; and a large packet of Books, addressed, also under a cover to me, to Sir Benjamin Hobhouse, President of the Bath agricultural Society; with a Letter from Josiah Quincy Corresponding Secretary, to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, recommending the packet to my care. Mr Forbes paid me a visit, and introduced a Mr Hazlehurst of Philadelphia, who told me he had met me at Mr Pitcairn’s at Hamburg in the year 1801. I had some leisure at the Office, and read several of Dr Franklin’s Letters, which are amusing. I was surprized that they should have ventured to print the Letter to Mr Hutton, page 38. in which there is a sortie against the king of England more violent than any thing I had ever read— The Letter to Mrs Thompson at Lisle p. 16 is gaillarde for a man in his 70th. year— That to Mrs Bache p. 46 is a humorous burlesque upon the order of the Cincinnati— That to Strahan the king’s printer p. 52. he says written over the second bottle of Madeira; humorous and characteristic. There is scarcely a Letter without some useful remark; but it is sometimes repeated to different Correspondents One particularly upon Avarice and Ambition is repeated in three Letters, almost in the same words— I stopped at Hunter’s shop, late Johnson’s, in St. Paul’s Church Yard; took an Unitarian pamphlet which my father has ordered me to procure for him and ordered a set of Hewlett’s Commentaries and annotations on the Bible, in five Volumes. I dined with Mr W. Vaughan, in Dunster Court N. 1. Mincing Lane, in the same room where I first dined with him in 1783. and where I first met, one of the most pleasant friends I ever knew, William Vans Murray; now many years deceased. The company this time was small. Mr Sharpe, Member of Parliament, Coll. Aspinwall and A. H. Everett were my only acquaintance. Mr Sharpe has been in France and Italy since the last Session of Parliament. He supposes the Session now about to commence, will be extremely important, and says the Opposition will muster very strong, both of which I doubt. He says that Earl Gray will take a very prominent part in the debates, and that the Marquis of Wellesley is decidedly in the opposition and very desirous of being Minister. He quoted the saying of one of his whig Friends, that it would be more difficult to keep the present Ministry in than to turn them out— Mr Everett took a seat with me to his lodgings, and I reached home, about half-past twelve— The roads were very heavy.

16. VIII: A Heavy rain continued all the morning and carried off almost entirely the Snow that had fallen yesterday. Having risen so late, much of the writing of the day was lost— I read an hour or two in the pamphlet recommended to me by my father. Αιρεσεων ΑναϚαςις, a jocular attack upon the doctrine of the Trinity— To me the attempt at wit appears heavy and the facetiousness remarkably dull.— My father expresses in his Letter a curiosity to know the author of it— I enquired yesterday at the Bookseller’s, but they said they were not authorised to tell.— After the rain held up, I walked to Brentford and through the Sion-House Park; continued the Letter to W. Plumer but left it unfinished. After dinner while the boys were acting their play, finding that my unitarian droll, was too soporific, I played cribbage an hour to keep me awake.

17. VI:45. It was full daylight by the time I was dressed. By the first Post I received a Note from J. A. Smith, and a Letter from Alexander Glennie and Son. It was a reply to my Letter of the 3d. instant to James S. Glennie. They enclose a copy of the Sentence of the Vice-Admiralty Court in Jamaica, condemning the Sloop Mary and Cargo— Clark & Kempton’s case an extract of a Letter from Joseph Sladen, the Proctor in Doctors Commons, to the Glennie’s shewing the present state of the case in the Court of Appeals; and a printed circular from the Glennie’s themselves dated the 20th. of January 1817 announcing that they have resumed their business under the firm of Alexander Glennie and Son, by the recommendation, and with the promise of the support of Alexander Baring— Soon after breakfast, and as I was finishing my Letter to W. Plumer, J. M. Forbes came out to pay us a visit. J. A. Smith was with him, and they both stayed and dined with us. Smith brought out with him a Letter from himself, mentioning that a young Man had called at the Office with a Bill of Exchange, drawn by T. Sumter junr. Minister of the United States at Rio de Janeiro, upon the Baring’s for £500 Sterling, in favour of Mello and Pead; and a memorandum from the Baring’s that it cannot be accepted for want of order from the Government of the United States— The young man is to call again to-morrow— A Letter from T. Auldjo, Consul at Cowes, enclosing accounts and vouchers, of expenditures for destitute American Seamen. And a Letter
from Jas Maury Consul at Liverpool, enclosing a Statement of American Articles imported at Liverpool, in the year 1816. Forbes, who was one of my Classmates at Cambridge, and has been much of a wanderer about the world, was at Ghent, when the Peace was concluded. Since then he has passed upwards of a year in America, and is now returning to Copenhagen, with three Commissions. One as Consul General and Prize Agent in Denmark—and the two others as Consul General in Prussia, and in the Duchy of Mecklenburg. He is in an infirm state of health and suffers much with the Gout; but is nevertheless going with the intention of being married at Copenhagen— We had a long Session together till dinner time, during which he gave me much information of the state of politics in Boston, and among our common acquaintance in America— They left us about nine in the Evening and returned to London—

18. IV:45. The sky was perfectly clear and bright when I rose. I saw from my cabinet windows Spica, and the principal Stars of Virgo, the two bright Stars of Libra, and Jupiter just risen— Within half an hour, and while I was dressing, it clouded up, and no sky was to be seen. I wrote a Note to Lord Castlereagh, on the case of the Sloop Mary and Cargo, Clark & Kempton’s, and finished the Letter to Mr Plumer: this necessarily occasioned the postponement of the Journal— Something must always be postponed. I received a Note from W. Vaughan accepting the invitation to dinner; next Wednesday; and one from W. J. Burdett with an excuse owing to a previous engagement. Went into London with my wife and George— He and I walked through the Parks to Craven Street. The Office was crowded with Company from the moment when we arrived, until we left it after five O’Clock to return home. I found there Count George de Caraman the Secretary of the French Embassy; son of the Count Caraman whom I knew formerly at Berlin, and who is now French Ambassador at Vienna— This young man has been four years Secretary of the French Legation in the United States. He left two Papers, applying for certain documents said to have belonged to a Frenchman named Pinden, and alledged to have been deposited in the Office of the American Consul at Plymouth. Mr Thompson, the publisher of the translation of Alcedo, called and took the books that I had promised to lend him. He talked about the recent transactions in South-America; and particularly the new Portugues invasion of the revolted Spanish Province. He says they have taken Montevideo, and thinks they will subdue the Independent party there. The same man who came some days ago to offer the invention of the three bottomed ship, now came about another invention. A Gentleman has discovered a mode of extracting from corn, double the quantity of Saccharine matter that can be obtained by the process of malting. He wants to get a Patent for this invention in the United States, and came to enquire how he could do it— I told him no person other than a Citizen of the United States could take out a Patent there; and that he must also make Oath to the originality of the invention— G. Boyd came in; arrived yesterday Morning from France— The young man from Pello and Mead’s brought Mr Sumter’s Bill of Exchange on the Baring’s. I gave him a Letter to them, requesting them to accept and pay the Bill, and charge it to the diplomatic fund— G. Joy, J. Winthrop and Jas. Grubb successively came in, and held us in various Conversation, until the Carriage came for us.— I spoke to Joy about the scruple made by Planta, against applying for a Treasury order to the Custom-House for the delivery to me of a Pipe of wine free of duties; on the ground that I had not imported it myself, but bought it here, already imported. Joy told me that Luffman had shewn him an order of that kind, in favour of the Portuguese Minister— He said he would see Luffman about it on Monday. Winthrop told me that Mr Burdett would have dined with me next Wednesday, but that both he Winthrop and Dr Cooke of Gower-Street, were engaged and could not come, and Burdett felt awkward at coming without any of his own acquaintance— He thought if Frend should come, Burdett would come with him. I sent several further Cards of invitation— A. H. Everett has concluded to stay here two or three Months longer before he goes to join Mr Eustis at Bruxelles— There was a packet forwarded by Mr Maury from Liverpool, but directed to his care as a Ship-Letter, marked with upwards of eleven shillings postage, and having from the appearance of the Seals, been broken open. It contained only four of Cobbett’s New-York Registers— Boyd gave me a pamphlet written by his uncle, on the British Finances— The box containing my Portrait by Van Huffel was yesterday received from Dover. We got home about seven O’Clock; & played Boston after dinner.

19. VI:45. Attended church with my wife and John— Prayers for the second Sunday after the Epiphany were read by Mr. Milman, and the Sermon was preached from Genesis III:23— “The Lord God sent him forth from the garden of Eden”—only part of the verse— It was of course upon the fall of man, and the discourse was well divided into the considerations of Man 1. in his first and glorious Estate— 2. in his fallen condition, and 3. in his hopes of redemption by the atonement of Christ— Dr Bond’s delivery becomes more disagreeable to me every time I hear him; His subject this day was a difficult one, and as little susceptible of matter for the edification of my mind, as any one that could have been selected— Yet it confirmed me in the opinion of the superiority of the Doctor’s Sermons to any others that I have heard in England. He married a couple, after the Communion Service and before the Sermon. The Misses Nicholas were here after Church. I was prevented by the rain from taking my usual walk— Mr G. Boyd came out to dine and pass the Night here— My Journal with the Newspapers of the day, and one of Cobbett’s New-York Register’s occupied all my leisure. Smith sent me out a Card of Invitation to dinner from Lord Castlereagh for the 6th: of February when the Queen’s Birth-day is to be celebrated.

20. VI: This Morning after Breakfast Mr Boyd returned to London— I answered T. Auldjo’s Letter, and wrote to N. G. Ingraham, enquiring after the papers stated by the widow Pinden, to have been sent in 1812 to the American Consulate at Plymouth— The case recommended by young Count Caraman— I also began despatch 68 to the Secretary of State which I had not time to finish. I walked to Brentford and through Sion House Park. After dinner we had Cards with the children, but my wife was so unwell that she was obliged to retire to bed before nine. [symbols]

21. V:15. The Morning was clear, and I had a view from my windows of the two Stars of the Scales in Libra, of the three in the head and first claw of Scorpio; of Antares, with Jupiter immediately over him, and of the principal Stars, in the serpent, and in the two knees of “Ophinchus huge”— Antares had just risen to be visible, and though a star of the first magnitude scarcely appeared to be of the third— The day breaks about six— I received by the Morning’s Post a Note from Saml: & J. Ward, enclosing a Letter from John Ellis, a young Man from New-York now in prison for debt. He applies as a Citizen of the United States, to the Representative of his Country for assistance, and his friends recommend him as a young man who will be entitled to some property, but who partly by misfortune, and partly by juvenile imprudence has got involved in great distress. I went alone to London; my wife had intended to go with me, but was too much indisposed— I found Boyd at the Office in Craven Street. There was a Note from W. Hamilton, the Under Secretary of State, informing me that the Lords of the Treasury under the peculiar Circumstances mentioned in my Note to Mr Planta, had sent an order to the Commissioners of the Customs, for the delivery to me of a Pipe of Madeira wine, purchased in this Country, free of duty. This was the day of payment for the Bill of James Holmes, formerly Consul at Newry which I had accepted— A person named Miers came and presented it, to whom I gave an order upon the Baring’s for the Amount— Mr Grubb at the request of my wife has been looking for a house for us, in London; and had found one in Dover Street which he thought would suit us: he had agreed that we should take it from the first of next Month subject to my approbation; but as I cannot give up the house in which we now reside without four weeks notice, I did not approve of this agreement. The woman belonging to the house came to ask what was my determination— I informed her I should not take it— Chitty likewise called, and Mr Addams of the associated Procters in the Admiralty, Cresswell Addams, to enquire if I was ready to settle their Account against the United States— I had not examined them, but promised to do it immediately, and to give them in a very few days notice of the result— Returning home, I saw the Moon and Venus in conjunction— The day was fine and the Evening cool. After dinner I read over some of Cobbett’s New-York Registers.

22. IV:45. Letter to Alexander Glennie and Son, in reply to theirs of the 16th. Received a Letter from the Baring’s enclosing one from G. W. Erving at Madrid. The Baring’s at my request have accepted T. Sumter’s bill, from Rio de Janeiro but they say he has no credit open with them, and that their Instructions are to advance monies only upon specific Credits— Also that they have written to the Government respecting former Bills drawn by Sumter upon them, and although they have answers to Letters of much later date, have no instructions upon that subject. Erving speaks of the state of our Relations with Spain as precarious— G. Boyd has received an order from the War Department, to make a purchase of Books upon Military Subjects, with instructions to refer to me for advice— He asked me to make out a list for him, and I was great part of this morning selecting one from a large Catalogue. My writing was proportionably abridged. Walk with George to Brentford, and through Sion-House Park— We had Company to dinner. Dr Bollmann
and his two daughters, A. H. Everett, G. Joy, J. C. Montgomery, Mr Sharp and W. Vaughan— As usual more than half our company failed. Mrs Everett was unwell— From Mr Aspland I have received no answer to the card of invitation. Boyd promised he would come, but did not. Mr Burdett, Dr Cooke, Mr Frend, and Mr Winthrop, sent excuses. Forbes declined for his infirmities, and J. A. Smith was engaged to go this Evening to a Ball at the London Tavern— My wife also was unwell, and kept her chamber, so that including the children we sat down only twelve at table. The party was nevertheless pleasant and cheerful— The company left us between ten and eleven.

23. VI:15. Received three Letters from Jas Maury; one introductory to a Mr Hobson, and the others relating to a packet of Books, which he has received for me from Philadelphia, charged with £19:16:8. Postage. I wrote a Note to W. Hamilton of the Foreign Department, and Letters to the Brothers Baring, to J. A. Smith and to A. Loughman, and sent Antoine with them to London. Walk with George to Acton. Began the Examination of the Accounts of Cresswell and Addams the Proctors at Doctors Commons. Received by the Evening’s Post, a Note from Lord Castlereagh, concerning the case of the William and Mary; a refusal to interfere with the proceedings of the Admiralty Court— A Note from W. Hamilton, asking explanations about two boxes, brought from France, by G. Boyd, for my wife, containing articles of wearing apparel; taken from Boyd at the Custom-House at Dover, and sent to the Custom-House at London— Smith wrote a Note in my name to Hamilton asking an order from the Treasury for the delivery of these boxes, but without mentioning their marks or contents. A despatch from James Monroe Secretary of State of 3. December, enclosing a printed copy of the President’s Message to Congress, of that day; and another newspaper— A Letter from T. Auldjo, Consul at Cowes. A Bill from Thomas, the Silversmith; and a Card of thanks for obliging enquiries from Mrs Delafield, who was lately confined, to my wife— I read in the Evening a few pages of Pillet. My wife was bled.

24. V:15. Received this Morning a Letter from Coll. Aspinwall the Consul, informing me that the Board of Controul for the affairs of India, have it in contemplation to bring in a Bill, at the ensuing Session of Parliament, for levying a duty of 30 per Cent, upon the exportation in any foreign bottom, of all Articles the produce or manufacture of the British possessions in India, and with a drawback of 15 per Cent if the goods are landed in England— A Letter from J. A. Smith, asking me to bring to town, Jouffroy’s Communication about the Steam Frigate— From Washington Irving at Birmingham, introducing his nephew Lewis G. Irving; and by the Evening’s Post a second Note from W. Hamilton, enquiring what are the contents of the two boxes, for which an order from the Lords of the Treasury to the Custom-house had been requested— I had answered the first Note this Morning, and had written Letters to my Mother, to T. Auldjo, and to T. Dickason and Co.— I walked to Gunnersbury and Brentford, and nearly finished the examination of the Accounts and Documents of Cresswell and Addams. Passed the Evening at Cards, with the boys.

25. VII: Finished the examination of the Bills of Cresswell and Addams. There are six Cases of Appeals from Sir William Scott’s decisions to the Lords Commissioners of Appeal; all cases in which the decrees of the judge, condemning the property were confirmed, and all cases of mere robbery of the property of American Citizens— The Bills of Costs of these Proctors amount to an average of two hundred pounds Sterling in each case I am instructed by the Secretary of State to settle these Accounts if I find them reasonable, and so far as they were authorized by the then American Consul, General Lyman. The authorization of the Consul appears to be sufficiently proved, but the reasonableness of the charges depends upon the question whether they are customary. I took one of the Bills to London, and left it with Smith, to shew to some of his acquaintance among the lawyers, to ascertain if the charges are such as are usually made and allowed— George went with me to town, but I walked almost to the Kensington Turnpike. Just as I reached the Office in Craven-Street, Mr Page was going into it. I sent Robert, with the Note for W. Hamilton at the foreign Office, and with the Packet of Books from Josiah Quincy, to Sir Benjamin Hobhouse. Mrs Adams had sent some Articles for Micklam. Mr Page gave me an account of the
proceedings in the Court of King’s Bench upon the case which he is managing of the American George Cook, against Maxwell, as Governor of Sierra Leone— He says he followed my advice in the Summer, and presented himself to the Court as ready for trial; but the Government retreated. The Attorney General after some manoeuvering obtained a continuance of the Cause to obtain copies of the indictment against Cook, at the Court of Sierra Leone. The Government wish to procrastinate, merely to get the benefit of the chapter of Accidents; and may perhaps succeed; for Cook has been at the point of death with a fever, and is yet not out of danger. Page also told me of some new discoveries, much to the discredit of Zachary Macaulay, and the Directors of the African Institution, which he says is one of the greatest bubbles, that ever duped or disgraced this Nation— There were a succession of visitors at the Office until five O’Clock when I had ordered the Carriage— A Mr Hobson from Liverpool who had brought me a Letter of introduction from Mr Maury— Intends to leave town for Liverpool on Monday and offered to take charge of any thing I might have to send. A Mr John Thomas Jennings, son as he told me of a very eminent Lawyer in the State of Maryland came with a complaint, and a long Story, of his having taken passage in an English vessel at Antwerp, to come to England; of the Captain’s having sailed without him, and brought away all his baggage; of his having left it here in London in custody of two Jews named Cohen, who refuse to deliver it up, unless he, Jennings will pay for his passage. He applied to the Lord Mayor, for redress; but the Lord Mayor told him the case was not within his Jurisdiction. He offered indeed on Jenning’s telling him that he was an American Gentleman, to send the City Marshal with him to the two Jews; which Jennings declined. Jennings stated himself to be in great distress for want of his baggage, and also for want of money. I told him it was not in my power to help him. His remedy must be in a Court of Law. He said the expences of the suit would cost him more than to submit to the imposition and redeem his baggage, by paying the Captain’s demand. He went away dissatisfied. General Boyd who came in shortly afterwards came in, and told me that Jennings had imposed upon him and borrowed money of him under another pretence of having come from the United States as Secretary to a Coll. La Croix whom General Boyd said he knew to be himself an impostor. Next came Mr John Ward of the house of Samuel Ward, with a long story and many papers, concerning John Ellis, the young Man who wrote to me for money to get him released from Prison. The Ward’s he said while doing business as merchants, from which he said they had now both retired, had been in some relations of business with Ellis’s father. Business which Ward assured me had been of no profit to them; but on the contrary had occasioned some loss to them. On Ellis’s Death however they had remitted to his Executors a balance due to him of more than £8000 Sterling, to the great satisfaction of the Executors who had entertained no expectation that the balance would have been within £1500 so high as it proved. He shewed me a Letter of very warm thanks, and acknowledgments from the Executors on the closing of the accounts. Last year this young John Ellis, with his elder brother Henry Ellis came to England with Letters of Recommendation but not of credit from their Mother to the Ward’s. These Letters they did not deliver, until they had got into difficulty about money. Then Henry Ellis applied to them for £50 Sterling which they supplied him on the assurance that it was all he wanted, taking his Bill upon his Mother.— This Bill was paid; but the Mother at the same wrote to the Ward’s that if they furnished him any more Money, not to take his Bills upon her, but upon the Executors of the fathers Will, of which she was one, and not upon them to the amount of more than one thousand dollars a year, which was the allowance to him by the Will until he should come of age— Mr Ward shewed me this Letter, and said that the provisions of the Will, were the same, for both the brothers— But immediately after they had supplied the £50, and before the Mother’s answer was received both the brothers were imprisoned for debts, and the Ward’s advanced £210 more, to obtain the release of Henry the elder brother, and pay half the cost of his passage home, the other half being to be paid on his arrival in America— John had also added to his own embarrassments, by assisting his brother also with money. Henry arrived at New-York early in the autumn; by him John and the Ward’s wrote to the Mother and to the Executors, but no answer has been received from either; no payment, nor even promise of payment of the Bills for the advances made by the Ward’s— John is nearly two years under age, and there is no legal means of recovering any money that might be advanced for him— I had begun by asking Mr Ward, if he and his brother would make themselves responsible for the repayment of the money, if I should advance it to obtain the young Man’s release. He said no— That if there had been any security for the repayment, they themselves would have advanced the money, and there would have been no occasion for the application to me. That they had from time to time advanced him to the amount of thirty
Pounds for his subsistence in prison. He shewed me duplicates of John’s Letters, written in December, to his brother Henry, to his Mother, and to two of the Executors of the Will; and he left them with me, with a request that I would forward them which I promised. I told him that under these circumstances it was impossible for me to advance the money, but I would answer the young Man’s Letter— His Letter to his brother is in a tone of affecting and mild reproach— He says he had made application to Mr Charles King, at Paris, for assistance, and receiving no answer had obtained of some person to ask of Mr King whether he had received the Letter. He said he had, but had nothing to do about it— Mr John Sergeant of Philadelphia, came with a Mr Whatmore. He arrived in town last Evening, and brought me Letters of introduction from my father, mother and brother, from Mr Monroe, S. Ewing & Dr S. Miller formerly of New-York, but now of Princeton College. He had also despatches for Messrs: Gallatin, Eustis, Pinkney & Hughes, which he left with me. He said that a despatch for me had been taken from him on board ship before he arrived at Liverpool— It was the one I received the day before yesterday, and came charged with eleven shillings and ten pence Postage. Mr Sergeant is one of the members of Congress from the City of Philadelphia, and a Director of the Bank of the United States. He comes upon a Mission from that Institution, to borrow ten Millions of Dollars in specie, upon a deposit of United States Stock— I suppose upon the proposal made from Reid, Irving & Co. by Renwick. While Sergeant was with me, there came in a man named Suter, who after waiting in the Office above an hour, asked me if I would let him have some money and take a Bill upon Mr Daniel Suter of Philadelphia— I declined. He said he had come here to obtain £23:10 of prize-money, due to him for service, in the British Navy, into which he had been impressed; and that he was well acquainted with Mr Sergeant, who was to have come in the same vessel from Philadelphia that he did— He had spoken quite familiarly to Mr Sergeant while he had been in the office, but Sergeant had not much noticed him— This man had been at the office some days ago, and then pretended to be a relation of mine; but said nothing of that, this day. I referred him to Mr Sergeant. Mr A. H. Everett came in and occupied the rest of the time till five. He enquired if he could go with me next Tuesday to attend the opening of the Session of Parliament in the House of Lords. I thought he could not; but desired Mr Smith to see Mr Chester, between this and Tuesday, and enquire. Everett asked also about obtaining admission under the gallery of the House of Commons, and Smith engaged to take him with him. General Boyd’s visit also had been to ask to be presented to the Prince Regent at the Levee— But there being so many people at the Office he mentioned his wish only to Smith— We reached home about seven O’Clock, and amused the Evening with Cards.

26. V:15. I attended with my three Sons, at the dissenting Meeting-House, on Boston Terrace— The Services were performed there by a young man named Geary— The auditory did not exceed seventy persons including ourselves— The service was precisely, in the same form as that of our congregational Churches. A short introductory prayer— A chapter in the Bible read. A Hymn Sung. Long prayer. Second Hymn. Sermon. Third Hymn, and concluding prayer. The whole Service took about an hour and a quarter. The Sermon, half an hour. The text was Isaiah I. V:6–11.6. “Seek ye the Lord, while he may be found, call ye upon him, while he is near: 7. Let the wicked forsake his way, and the unrighteous man his thoughts: and let him return unto the Lord, and he will have mercy upon him; and to our God for he will abundantly pardon. 8. For my thoughts, are not your thoughts, neither are your ways my ways, saith the Lord. 9. For as the heavens are higher than the earth, so are my ways higher than your ways, and my thoughts, than your thoughts. 10. For as the rain cometh down, and the snow from heaven, and returneth not thither, but watereth the Earth, and maketh it bring forth and bud, that it may give seed to the sower, and bread to the eater: 11. So shall my word be, that goeth forth out of my mouth: it shall not return unto me void, but it shall accomplish that which I please, and it shall prosper in the thing whereunto I sent it.” The Hymns and Psalms, were a collection, published about 1795. by four of the Unitarian dissenting Ministers, Rees, Jervis, Morgan and another, and are nearly the same as those published by Dr Belknap in Boston. The Sermon was written in a very good plain Style, and the delivery was above mediocrity— This Assembly is said to be so very small, because about half the Society have left them, and joined the Church at Ealing from unwillingness to share in their new Unitarian Principles— Mr W. Jones Burdett and J. Winthrop came out from London and paid us a visit. Winthrop
is going to-morrow, to spend some weeks at Liverpool and Glasgow. Mr Burdett who is one of the ardent reformers spoke of the approaching Session of Parliament, and of the late Meetings of the Delegates from the Petitioners for Annual Parliaments in various parts of the Country— His Conversation upon the subject is remarkably cool and moderate— I walked with George to Brentford and Ealing before dinner, and in the Evening read the Newspapers; having this day in addition to the Observer and Examiner, the first number of a new weekly publication called the Literary Gazette. I read also the prefaces to Hewlett’s Commentary on the Bible.

27. IV:45. After finishing the Journal of Saturday and yesterday, I wrote Letters to F. Freeling Post-Master General, upon the subject of the Books charged with near £20 postage, received for me by Mr Maury at Liverpool and of the despatch for me taken from Mr Sergeant, and sent to me by the Post-Office, and to John Ellis in answer to his application to me for Money— I also received Letters, from C. Hughes, at Paris, where he has been much noticed by Persons of distinction—from A. Loughnan about the Pipe of Madeira wine— There is yet some difficulty about the order from the Treasury for delivering it to me free of duty, and he writes to ask me to procure another order. In the Evening I had a line from J. A. Smith, who wishes to shew Mr Reeves the Papers of Crosby’s case; and from Mr Eustis, enclosing a despatch for Mr Monroe, and a Letter for A. Hill. Boston; brought by Sir Grenville Temple from Bruxelles— G. Boyd came out from London to dine and pass the Night here; and kept us up till one in the Morning.

28. VII:45. Nearly three hours later than my time. I received an answer from N. G. Ingraham Consul at Plymouth, concerning the papers claimed by Mrs Pinden— It appears they were taken by the Transport Board— I went into London, immediately after Breakfast. My wife, G. Boyd, and my Son John went with me. Boyd left us at Hyde Park Corner, to go to the French Ambassador’s for a Passport— He is going immediately to France, and intends to embark, by the 15th. of next Month at Havre, for the United States. At Craven Street, I found a Letter from Samuel O’Malley, dated Kilboyne Castlebar, Ireland, enclosing one for George O’Malley, whom he supposes to be the person employed some time by General Armstrong in the American Legation at Paris; which Letter he requests me to transmit— There were also Notes, from Sir Benjamin Hobhouse, acknowledging the receipt of the parcel of Books that I sent him last Saturday— From Mr Boyle requesting me to obtain for him an Order from a Peer for admission at the House of Lords to hear the Regent’s Speech; but it was too late to make the Application— Mr Chester’s Note informed me that the Prince Regent would open the Session of Parliament at 2. O’Clock— And there was a Notice from the Lord Chamberlain’s Office, that the Queen’s Birth-day drawing Room, which had been fixed for the 6th. of February, was postponed to the 20th.— I ordered the Carriage at half past one. Mr Boyle called; and Mr A. H. Everett, who had been promised an order for admission, for himself and Mrs Everett, by an order from Sir Benjamin Bloomfield, but was disappointed— It was about twenty minutes before two when the Carriage came— Mr Smith and myself were dressed to be present at the Ceremony. Mrs Adams and John went with us, to stay in the Carriage and see the show— But the crowd of People and of Carriages was so excessive, and the passage was so much obstructed, that the Clock at the Horse-Guards as we passed it was within three minutes of two, and it was near half an hour later before we reached the door of the Parliament-House— The Prince had nearly finished his Speech, and the doors of the House of Lords were closed so that it was impossible to obtain admission. My error had been in not ordering my Carriage at one, instead of half-past one— We turned round and moved slowly up Parliament Street, till the Prince passed by us on his return. As we turned round we saw Viscount Hampden, in his Robes as a Peer, in his Carriage next behind ours, and in like manner belated— The Prince passed us within ten minutes after we returned. A mixture of low but very audible hissing; of faint groaning, and still fainter attempts to raise a shout among the populace, contrasted with the heavy magnificence of the gilded, but tasteless and clumsy State Coach, the gorgeous splendor of the golden harnesses, and the sky-blue silk ribbons, with which the eight cream coloured royal horses were bedizened. The populace manifested no symptoms of riot, but a troop of horsemen preceded the Carriage, with drawn swords pressing back the crowd, preventing their approach to the Carriage, and urged by a leader constantly repeating in a tone of extreme earnestness “keep them back! keep them back!” There were among the crowd, great numbers of very wretched and ill looking persons— They talked with more or less freedom— We heard one man say “he is gone into a strong hysteric[”]—another said “throw mud at him”— He has been so long accustomed to this sort of treatment from the populace, that he may perhaps have grown callous to it; but I did not envy him his feelings— We returned to Craven
Street exactly at three. I found there a card from Mr John Auldjo of Finsbury Square with a Letter from his brother T. Auldjo, the Consul at Cowes, requesting me to give him the order upon the Baring’s, to discharge his Consular Bill against the United States— And a Letter from Broom and Herriss Carpet Manufacturers, stating that Mr G. Boyd, had referred them to me, for the assurance that he was authorized to make purchases on account of the American Government for the Commissioners of the Public Buildings at Washington— Mr Forbes called at the Office and a Mr Moore of New-York. Smith wrote for me, one order upon the Baring’s in favour of T. Auldjo, to be given to his brother who will send a receipt for it— An Answer to Broom and Herriss, assuring them that G. Boyd is authorised to make purchases for the American Government. And a Letter to C. Hughes at Paris, enclosing to him that for George O’Malley.— I asked Smith to see A. Loughnan to-morrow, and see if he can get an explanation of the Treasury Order about the wine.— John bought himself a flageolet, upon which he wishes to learn to play. We came home at seven. I found I could not read after dinner. Mrs Adams was quite unwell the greatest part of the day.

29. V:30. The humours of the populace yesterday were, it seems not confined to the hissing, groaning, mock-shouting and evil-speaking which we heard. The Prince-Regent’s Carriage entered St. James’s Park at the Horse-Guards. He returned to St. James’s Palace, and on his way thither after passing by Carlton House, the window at the left hand was broken by bullets shot from an air-gun, or stones thrown by the rabble. The Duke of Montrose, Master of the Horse, and Lord James Murray, a Lord of the Bedchamber were in the Carriage with the Prince. Lord James Murray was examined before both houses of Parliament, and declared that he had not the least doubt that the first fractures were made by two bullets, shot from above, it might be from a tree: but no report was heard, no bullets found in the carriage; and the opposite window, though up, was not broken, and immediately after, a large stone was thrown, which shattered the glass to pieces— The two Houses voted a dutiful address to the Prince, expressing their horror at this outrage, and requesting him to take measures to discover the perpetrator. The debate in the House of Commons upon the Address in answer to the Speech, was interrupted by this episode, and adjourned to this day.— We came through St. James’s Park on our return home last Evening, about five. The crowd were then entirely dispersed. We stopped at Cumberland-House in St. James’s Palace, to enquire how the Duchess of Cumberland was. She had been delivered the day before of a still-born daughter, and was doing well— This Morning I received a Letter from G. Boyd dated yesterday, enclosing a blank order on a stamp, addressed to the Secretary at War, for £180 Sterling, but not signed. The object of it is to purchase Books for the War Department. At the same time my wife received a Letter from him last Evening 1/2 past 7. At the Cannon Coffee-House, just ready to start for Brighton. I received also a Letter from the Brothers Baring & Co. enclosing two Orders drawn by me upon them, for payments to J. Maury, Consul at Liverpool on account of Seamen, with triplicate receipts for the money which they request me to sign— I suppose they are sent to me by mistake— I wrote despatch 69 to the Secretary of State, walked to Gunnersbury and Brentford, and after dinner, read with difficulty several Chapters of Pillet— The weather has been for several days remarkably warm, and the Crocuses under my windows are opening. I first observed them the day before yesterday. The birds about the house are singing as in April, and the buds of the hedges are ready to open.

30. V:30. Wrote to G. W. Erving, and immediately after Breakfast I went to London. Walked until the Carriage overtook me, between the Hammersmith and Kensington Turnpikes. Stopped at Richardson the Wine Merchants N. 96 Pall-Mall, and then at my Office in Craven Street.— I had received by the Morning’s Post, from Lord Castlereagh—a Cover, enclosing two printed Copies of the Prince Regent’s Speech at the opening of the Session of Parliament— A public Note, concerning the misconduct of British Officers on the Canadian Lakes, some time last Summer, with enclosures. A copy of a Letter from Sir J. C. Sherbrooke to Earl Bathurst, and of one from H. Goulburn, under Secretary of State to Lord Bathurst, to W. Cooke, under Secretary of State in the Foreign Department, transmitting it. Sherbrooke writes that he has received Earl Bathurst’s Instructions to give orders for discountenancing all such misconduct in future, and has given orders accordingly— A private Note, postponing the invitation to dinner, from the 6th. to the 20th: of February,
the celebration of the Queen’s Birth-day having been thus postponed— From Coll: Aspinwall a Letter with his Accounts of disbursements for destitute Seamen, during the last year— The Accounts I found at the Office— From A. H. Everett a Letter requesting me to bring with me to town, the Volume of Constitutions of the United States. From my Office I went to N. 12. Bucklersbury, to see A. Loughnan: He was at Lloyd’s Coffee whence he came out and spoke to me. The mistake in the order from the Treasury to the Commissioners of the Customs and Excise for the delivery of the Madeira Wine to me, free of duty was that it was for a Hogshead, instead of a Pipe— It made an application for a new Order necessary. I went to the Counting-House of the Baring’s— Returned the two orders upon which they had paid money for James Maury, and the blank receipts they had sent me, which I shewed them I could not sign— And I read to them the paragraph in my Instruction from the Secretary of State, authorising me to give these Orders, and stating that the Consuls are to be responsible for the receipt of the Money, and not I. They had received this Morning a Letter from G. Boyd at Brighton— Alexander Baring is at Paris, making arrangements for a loan to the French Government— I took a check for £500. and received the money at their Bankers. Martin, Stone and Martin 68. Lombard Street— At 32. Cornhill I took a writing ring, rather larger than that I have hitherto used, and which I find too small— Walked back to Craven Street. Smith wrote a Note for me to W. Hamilton asking a new order from the Treasury for the wine— At 7 in the Evening I was at home; and after dinner read the debates in both houses of Parliament last Evening upon the Address in Answer to the Regent’s Speech— Received an Answer from F. Freeling the Postmaster, to the Letter I wrote him last Monday.

31. VI:30. I sent Antoine to London, to Richardson’s in Pall Mall, but he returned without having accomplished the business for which I sent him. Wrote to James Maury. Walk to Hanwell and Ealing. Met a young woman who was falling into a convulsion fit. She was walking in company with three others, two of them young Girls. I came up with them just in time to hold her up from falling to the ground. She was in a strong convulsion about ten minutes, when two Gentlemen in a Gig came up; stopp’d and offered their assistance— I asked them to let her be put into their Carriage and taken home; to which they readily assented, but she recovered so as to be able to stand and walk, and her companions declined using the Gig. She walked off with them. I came home and began a Letter to my Mother— While at dinner I received a Letter from T. Booyer formerly one of the Seamen of the ship Baltimore, but now at Liverpool. He enquires about his wages— Also two ship-Letters from Liverpool, which upon opening, I found were from W. Shaw of South-Carolina, and to James Grubb. In the Evening I read Lord Cochrane’s answer to an Address from his Constituents and several Chapters of Pillet.

Day. The range of my time of rising during the Month has been from IV:30 to VIII. O’Clock— The average at V:58. My constant occupation has been as usual, journal-writing and correspondence— The index-writing having ceased excepting from day to day, I have had more time for writing Letters; and have diminished a little my file of Letters to be answered. Twice a week I have been to London. I seldom find an hour for reading any thing but the Newspapers.
